article_text:
Note: The Crimean peninsula was annexed by Russia in 2014, but the region is not internationally recognised as part of Russia.

Source: Natural Earth; United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA); Worldpop.org; Ukrainian officials; Janes; Institute for the Study of War with AEI’s Critical Threats Project (Russian-occupied territory data as of 3 p.m. EST, April 3); UK Ministry of Defence; Reuters

russian occupiers fired at settlements in Kharkiv region 54 times over the past 24 hours: there are casualties

Photo: Kharkiv Regional Prosecutor's Office

On Monday, russian troops struck 54 times in the Kharkiv region and the city of Kharkiv

Rubryka reports, referring to the head of Telegram of the Head of Regional Military Administration Oleh Sinehubov.

According to the leader, 6 people died and 8 were injured.

"Over the past day, the occupiers struck 54 strikes from various types of long-range weapons: artillery strikes, mortar, and tank shelling, MLRS shelling.

The districts of Saltivka, Piatyhatky, Oleksiivka, Kholodna Hora, Derhachi, Barvinkove, Chuhuiv were affected.

Among the civilian population, there are victims of yesterday's shelling in Kharkiv and Chuhuiv. In Kharkiv and the district, there are 4 dead, and 3 people were hospitalized. In the Chuhuiv district, there are 2 dead, 5 injured.

During the day, the occupiers damaged houses, cars, and agricultural machinery in Barvinkove. Residents are encouraged to sign up for train evacuation.

We also recommend that residents of Lozova be safe, free evacuation trains run through the village. For more information, contact the local government," the statement said.

Sinehubov also stressed that the authorities continue to provide the city of Kharkiv and the region with humanitarian aid.

Food products are distributed to Nova Poshta and Ukrposhta distribution points, and for targeted assistance in the city of Kharkiv and the community of the Kharkiv region.

"Kharkiv region is ready for any scenario, our Armed Forces of Ukraine are on the positions and defending the region. We must keep a strong rear," the head of the region stressed.

Updated April 8, 2022 at 3:25 PM ET Editor's Note: Some of the images in this story are graphic. Sergei Supinsky / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 7: A woman surveys the damage to her home in the outskirts of Ivankiv, in northern Ukraine. Russian troops are leaving scenes of devastation — flattened apartment buildings, mass graves and bodies lying in the streets — as they leave the area around Kyiv. Millions are displaced, either finding refuge in Western countries, like Poland, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and Moldova, or shelters in cities where the situation is less dire, like Lviv. Here is what it looks like on the ground in Ukraine: Copyright 2022 NPR. To see more, visit https://www.npr.org. Andriy Andriyenko / AP / AP April 8: A fragment of a Tochka-U missile lies on the ground following an attack on a railway station in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine. A missile hit the crowded station that was serving as an evacuation point for civilians fleeing the war. Officials said Friday 50 people had been killed — five of them children — and nearly 100 more were injured in the strike. Petros Giannakouris / AP / AP April 7: Oksana Gavrielutca, 41, (from left) sits at the back of a bus with her children Oleg, 18, Diana, 17, and Vlad, 5, after they fled from the village of Snigiriovka, in southern Ukraine. Anastasia Vlasova / Getty Images / Getty Images April 7: Rescue workers remove rubble from a residential area in Borodianka, near Kyiv. The Russian retreat from towns near Kyiv revealed scores of civilian deaths and the full extent of devastation from Russia's failed attempt to seize the capital. Andriy Andriyenko / AP / AP April 8: Cars sit in front of a train station damaged by Russian shelling in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine. Fadel Senna / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 7: A woman is helped onto a train near Severodonetsk, as she tries to flee the country's Donbas region. Evgeniy Maloletka / AP / AP April 7: A destroyed tank sits in a yard in Chernihiv, in northern Ukraine. Fadel Senna / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 8: Bodies are covered in plastic sheets after an explosion killed at least 50 people at a train station in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine. The site was the center of civilian evacuation efforts the government called for ahead of anticipated aggression by Russia in the area. Andriy Andriyenko / AP / AP April 8: A man hugs a woman after Russian shelling at the railway station in Kramatorsk. Evgeniy Maloletka / AP / AP April 7: People walk bicycles past apartment buildings destroyed by shelling in Chernihiv, in northern Ukraine. Fadel Senna / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 7: Smoke rises near the city of Severodonetsk, in the country's Donbas region, as the Russian military's invasion continues. Chris McGrath / Getty Images / Getty Images April 7: Cemetery workers unload the bodies of civilians killed in and around Bucha, on the outskirts of Kyiv, before they're transported to the morgue. Felipe Dana / AP / AP April 6: Ukrainian soldiers walk next to heavily damaged residential buildings in Irpin, on the outskirts of Kyiv. Bulent Kilic / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 6: A young girl and her dog arrive at a center for internally displaced persons in Zaporizhzhia, some 124 miles northwest of Mariupol. Fadel Senna / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 6: A shelled home burns in Severodonetsk, in the Donbas region in eastern Ukraine, as Ukrainian officials urge residents in the east to evacuate or "risk death" ahead of a feared ramping up of Russian activity in the area, which Moscow has declared its top prize. Vadim Ghirda / AP / AP April 6: A cat sits between large caliber rounds of ammunition abandoned by retreating Russian forces or retrieved from destroyed fighting vehicles in the village of Andriivka, in eastern Ukraine. Chris McGrath / Getty Images / Getty Images April 6: A man pushes his bike through debris and destroyed Russian military vehicles on a street in Bucha, where the Ukrainian government has accused Russian forces of committing a "deliberate massacre." Alexey Furman / Getty Images / Getty Images April 6: Yurii, 41, who serves in the Ukrainian military, stands in his apartment in Hostomel, on the outskirts of Kyiv, as he gathers things to take with him. The suburb of Ukraine's capital city was occupied for more than a month by Russian forces until they retreated to Belarus last week. Joe Raedle / Getty Images / Getty Images April 6: Children look at the sandbags that cover the windows at the Smart English pre-school in Lviv, in western Ukraine. The sandbags were put in place to help lessen the potential impact of an air strike amid Russia's ongoing invasion. Chris McGrath / Getty Images / Getty Images April 6: A police officer stands behind the body of a civilian allegedly shot by Russian forces on a road in Bucha, on the outskirts of Kyiv. Evgeniy Maloletka / AP / AP April 7: A boy holds a loaf of bread he received as part of humanitarian aid being handed out in front of a school in Chernihiv, in northern Ukraine. Nicolas Garcia / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images April 6: A residential building in the town of Borodianka, northwest of Kyiv, was destroyed in Russia's invasion. Rodrigo Abd / AP / AP April 6: Cemetery workers load the corpses of civilians killed in Bucha, on the outskirts of Kyiv, to be transported to the morgue.

Editor's Note: Please be aware that some of the images in this story are graphic.

Russian troops are leaving scenes of devastation — flattened apartment buildings, mass graves and bodies lying in the streets — as they leave the area around Kyiv.

Millions are displaced, either finding refuge in Western countries, like Poland, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and Moldova, or shelters in cities where the situation is less dire, like Lviv.

article_author: ['Melissa Macaya', 'Jason Kurtz', 'Maureen Chowdhury', 'Aditi Sangal', 'Helen Regan', 'Travis Caldwell', 'Ben Church', 'Lianne Kolirin', "Seán Federico O'Murchú"]
article_text:
A pair of Democratic lawmakers is asking US President Joe Biden to increase cybersecurity assistance to Ukraine and European allies in the aftermath of a hack that disrupted service at a key Ukrainian internet service provider last month.

In a letter to Biden on Tuesday shared with CNN, Sen. Ed Markey and Rep. Bill Keating, both of Massachusetts, expressed concern that Russia could lash out with further cyberattacks in Ukraine or with hacking that tests NATO’s resolve as Russian military progress in Ukraine stalls.

A cyberattack last week on Ukrtelecom, which describes itself as Ukraine’s largest “fixed line” internet and phone provider, that reportedly knocked connectivity down at the telecom operator to 13% of its pre-war levels.

The lawmakers, both members of their respective chamber’s foreign affairs committees, want a newly formed cybersecurity bureau at the State Department to bolster US cooperation with Ukraine and European allies on cybersecurity issues, and in turn help defend against Russian hacking threats.

A spokesperson for Markey’s office called the $37 million the White House requested from Congress to run the bureau in fiscal 2023 a “strong starting point,” but said that it was “imperative” that the State Department coordinate with government entities like the US Cyber Command and the Department of Homeland Security that have long provided cybersecurity assistance to Ukraine.

CNN has reached out to the White House for comment.

Separate from the new bureau, the State Department has overseen millions of dollars in aid to Kyiv to shore up its networks in recent years. And the head of US Cyber Command, the military’s hacking unit, said Tuesday that the command dispatched a team of cyber specialists to Ukraine late last year to help defend Ukrainian infrastructure.

More on the hacks: While there have been an array of Russia-linked hacking incidents against Ukrainian organizations since the war began, there haven’t been the level of disruptive hacks against critical infrastructure that some analysts feared.

One exception was a cyberattack at the onset of the war that knocked out internet service for tens of thousands of satellite modems in Ukraine and elsewhere in Europe. US officials are investigating that incident as a potential state-sponsored Russian hack, CNN previously reported.

On March 21, Biden warned US business executives that “the magnitude of Russia's cyber capacity is fairly consequential and it's coming." So far, no consequential hacks on US organizations publicly attributed to the Russian government have emerged. But US officials continue to prepare for the possibility.

Markey and Keating asked Biden to “promptly” nominate an ambassador-at-large to lead the State Department’s new cybersecurity bureau. (Secretary of State Antony Blinken told State Department employees Monday that Biden would nominate someone for the role “very soon.”)

The Democratic lawmakers also want to know what lessons the Biden administration have learned from Russian hacking in Ukraine in recent weeks.

“How is the Administration coordinating U.S. government agencies to apply these lessons to shore up potential U.S. vulnerabilities as well as those of our allies and partners?” Markey and Keating wrote to Biden, asking for answers by April 29.
